title: [ACC] Will Automation Lead To Economic Crisis?
summary:
Key ideas:
- AI and automation will not lead to an economic crisis if the pace of automation does not exceed the pace of new job creation.
- Software for robots will not be similar to human minds, but will have natural language and image-understanding capabilities.
- Employment adapts to extensive automation, but changes took place over millennia, centuries, and decades.
- Researchers are actively trying to find ways to automate skills that computers cannot perform, and artificial general intelligence is becoming more general.
- Jobs that are likely to be automated soonest are repetitive, don't require fine dexterity, originality, or people skills.
- Automation can free up capital for business owners to hire more workers to do other jobs, so the number of workers hired may not decrease because of automation.
- Automation may put downward pressure on wages, while increasing the amount earned by capital owners.
- Automation can increase the amount of value produced per-capita, leading to an improved mean standard of living.
- As more jobs are automated, fewer hours per week or more days of leave per year could be an option, but preference for full-time work may remain.
- Machines becoming more capable does not necessarily mean more people will find themselves unable to find any job that AI can't do better.
- Machines with human-level ability could create more robots and invent new ways to make money and employ other machines.
- Even with all jobs being automated, people may still direct factories, resource extraction, and robots for all purposes, working as business owners.
- Economic gains that come from all automation will flow primarily to those who own the machines.

Key learnings:
- The cost of developing and deploying technology must fall below the cost of hiring workers for workers to be replaced.
- Some jobs may still be performed by humans because being done by a human is part of what is valued by some customers.
- As more jobs are automated, new jobs are expected to be created.
- New jobs for humans could still be created as technology automates more jobs.
- The pace of automation can lead to a crisis if it speeds up enough.
- Economic gains from automation flow largely to those who own the machines.
- Predicting the future of automation is difficult beyond a certain point.

Key questions:
- Are the concerns about the economic effects of automation valid?
- Will machines eventually surpass humans in all intellectual and dexterity tasks?
- What skills are likely to be automated soonest?
- How will the economic effects of automation differ from past technological innovations?
- Will automation lead to a crisis if it speeds up enough to not allow the market to adjust?
- To what extent will humans continue guiding the course of civilization beyond a certain point of machines surpassing human capabilities?
- How do we provide for those that can't find work, and who gets to decide?
